paragraph.htmltext: There are several relevant battery testing standards. Manufacturers/suppliers shall be familiar with these standards and shall utilize one or more of these standards as part of their testing process. Preproduction testing and production sampling should be extensive to confirm the design and production process. These testing procedures are not all inclusive. Tests are designed to confirm that the packs have the desired safety performance characteristics and are robust enough to resist abuse conditions should they arise. New modules shall pass specified test before they can be qualified as a production module.

The following paragraphs give lists of the different types of tests. Note that test procedure, samples, acceptance, will depend on the application in which the module is used and the characteristics of the module

Performance and reliability tests

The following performance tests are defined:

• Static capacity test constant current method: The purpose of this test is to establish the ampere hour and energy capacity provided at various discharge rates and temperatures as appropriate to establish vehicle application usage. This may be used as an application screening test to establish a need for sizing thermal management systems and energy performance. These tests may also verify performance as stated by the manufacturer.
  • Static capacity test constant power method: The purpose of this test is to establish the ampere hour and energy capacity provided at various discharge rates and temperatures as appropriate to establish vehicle application usage. This may be used as an application screening test to establish a need for sizing thermal management systems and energy performance. These tests may also verify performance as stated by the manufacturer.
  • Charge retention : The purpose of this test is to establish storage characteristics of a module(s) after recharge, i.e., stand loss, for the specific module technology and design. The test is not considered catastrophic; therefore modules may be repetitively used for different portions of this procedure.
  • Charge acceptance tests: The purpose of this test sequence is to establish how readily the module will accept charge at various temperatures. This is a complete charge acceptance test. This allows the vehicle manufacturer to estimate requirements for vehicle charger systems and thermal management requirements.
  • Peak power capability test: The purpose of this test sequence is to establish how readily the module will accept charge at various temperatures. This is a complete charge acceptance test. This allows the vehicle manufacturer to estimate requirements for vehicle charger systems and thermal management requirements.
  • Dynamic capacity test: This test is intended to measure the capacity of a battery module under dynamic discharge conditions similar to those which are imposed on electric vehicles in urban driving conditions. This dynamic cycle is scaled to a percentage of the rated or specified maximum power for the module to be tested.
• Moulded case stress at high ambient temperature

• Rated capacity test: determine if a battery meets the rated capacity declared by its manufacturer.
  • Capacity retention: determine the capacity retention of a battery.
  • Charge performance: To determine if a battery meets the performance requirements when used with a specific charger model.
  • Cycle life: determine cycle life by repeatedly charging and discharging
  • Extended charging at standard temperature: determine the ability of a battery to withstand extended charging time at standard temperature.
  • Storage test: determine the long-term storage capability of a battery
  • Effect of discharge rate on capacity delivery
  • Effect of temperature during discharge rate on capacity delivery
  • Effect of temperature during charge rate on capacity delivery
  • Effective internal resistance
  • Internal impedance
  • Charge efficiency
  • Overdischarge performance
  • Terminal endurance test : determine the ability of the battery to withstand repeated insertion and withdrawal operations to its connection mechanism and continue to deliver the required capacity
  • Thermal shock test
  • Mechanical shock

Abuse tests

During the design and development of a module, abuse tests should be executed to determine the response of the module to conditions or events which are beyond their normal operating range. The test procedures are described in standards according to which the test can be performed. The following abuse tests are described in standards ( IEC 62133,... â€¦ )

Battery enclosure tests

  • 250N steady force test
  • Mold stress relief test
  • Drop impact test
